titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 4 January 1848

After a Night of calm repose, I rose at half past 4. this morning. Fahrenheit 86. We breakfasted at 8 and took the train of Railway Cars which started at 9. A.M. from Baltimore for Philadelphia From Barnum’s hotel to the Dipot we went in a hack, then in the Cars drawn by horses to the borders of the City, where the horses were dismissed and the Locomotive took their place— At 3. P.M we reached the outskirts of Philadelphia where horses again took the place of the Locomotive and landed us at the depot in Market Street— Thence we proceeded to Jone’s Union Hotel in Chesnut Street— There we dined at the Lady’s ordinary and at half past 4. proceeded to Walnut Street Wharf and embarked in the Steamer which in an hour and a half landed us at Bristol— There we entered the train of Cars and passing through Trenton, Princeton, New Brunswick, Rahway, and Elizabeth Town and Newark at 9 in the Evening, brought us to Jersey City safe— We crossed the ferry and taking a hack at the fort of Cortland Street at 9.45 reached the Astor House New York. The transportation of this day from Baltimore to New York was but a trivial incident now common to hundreds every day in the year, and many days to thousands— I met on the way—Sundry fellow travellers with whom I had previous slightly remembered or forgotten acquaintance— The only remarkable one of which was the late Vice President of the United States John acting and self styled President of the United States John Tyler and his eldest son Robert— Civilities very polite but on my part cool passed between us— We had two German women with harps who played and sung popular songs accompanied by a Male Clarion, and made delightful music and pleasant pastime—

div.dateline:
New York. Saturday 15 August 1846—
Long Island. Norwich. Worcester. Boston. Quincy.
div.p: V. I rose after a good night at 5. Breakfasted at 6.15. Left the Astor house at 6.45. Crossed the battery ferry at 7. Took the Long Island train of Railway Cars from Brooklyn to Greenport 95 miles. Straggely barren strand all the way— Almost suffocated with dust. embarked at 11 in the Steamer Cinderella In company with Mr. & Mrs. John— A— Rockwell to Norwich their residence where they took leave of us— Cool rain from Norwich to Worcester. Then through Framingham Natick, Newton, Brighton, to Boston where just before 6 P.M. we alighted at the United States Hotel immediately opposite the Rail road Depot— Tea at the United States Hotel— At 1/2 past 7. the train of Cars of the Old Colony Railroad start— My Son was at the depot to meet us with his Son John Quincy— Both of them came out with us; as did Ex President of Harvard University Josiah Quincy—and Captain Dimmock a new resident of the town— The Stations where the Cars stop are at Savan Hill, Dorchester, Neponset, and Quincy each of which was announced by the Conductor as the Cars reached the Station— At the Depot at Quincy there was a considerable assemblage of persons, to whom as we alighted Captain Dimmock announced with a loud voice the arrival home of John Quincy Adams Representative in Congress of the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, whereupon there was a shout of three cheers. I apologized for not returning thanks, in a speech by the extinction of my voice— Our Carriage took us from the Depot home, where we found my Son’s wife with her two sons Charles and Henry to receive us— margaret Delany the waiting maid had reached here before us with Mrs. Eleanor Goods and her daughter Jane Goods— John Kirk and his wife Elizabeth were also here and welcomed us home—

V. Blessing, praise and supplication to God on first rising from bed, on returning to my earthly home, after an absence of nine months in the public service of my Country— Some discouragement of Soul follows the reflection, that my aspirations to live in the memory, of after ages, as a benefactor to my Country, and of mankind, have not received the sanction of my Maker— That the longing, of my Soul through a long life, to be numbered among the blessings bestowed by the Creator on the race of man is rejected, and after being trammelled and counteracted and disabled, at every step of my progress my faculties are now declining from day to day into mere helpless impotence— Yet—at the will of my heavenly Father why should I repine? Dr. John Pierce of Brookline preached at the Stone Temple this day by exchange with the Revd Mr. Lunt His morning Sermon was from Deuteronomy— 1—21— “Behold the Lord thy God hath set the land before thee; go up and possess it, as the Lord God of thy fathers hath said unto thee, fear not, neither be discouraged”— Dr. Pierce was not thinking of Texas, Mexico, or Oregon, but of the Reports of Caleb and Joshua on returning from their exploration of the Land of Canaan and of the heavenly land set before the Christian of the present age for his exploration and possession All his applications to our times were spiritual— Dr. Pierce dined with us— His afternoon Discourse was from Acts 11.26—“And the disciples were called Christians first in Antioch” This is an incident of historical fact very curious, and interesting upon which the commentary might have been broader and deeper Dr. Pierce is of the salt of the earth— I commenced reading the Book of Proverbs and with a view to go through the remainder of the Bible by the close of the present year I propose to read henceforth 4 chapters every day—

I return to a quiet home, and to more than voluntary repose My health apparently firmer than at any time within the last fifteen months, but shaking more and more. I rose with coming daylight but the sky was beclouded, and I could get neither a first sight of Sirius nor of the rising Sun— The first thing that riveted my attention to the progress of civilization and Society in my native Village was the rush by my windows of the train of Cars from Boston to Plymouth at 5.45. followed at 6.45 by the return train from Plymouth to Boston— I was all day thinking of a fixed steady specific occupation for the Season during the recess of Congress— I had an unexpected but only momentary morning visit from William. Clarkson. Johnson, from Utica, New York where he says he has opened a Lawyer’s Office, and has as much business as he can do— My only excursion this day was about sunset when I walked up to my Son’s House where I found them at tea—He went to bathe at Daniel Greenleaf’s landing and his wife came to my house with me— My wife was quite ill and almost the whole day confined to her bed. My Cousin Louisa Catherine Smith came out from Boston to spend the Summer with us— Evening visit from Ex President Josiah Quincy, who left me an invitation from his Son Mayor of Boston to attend at the breaking ground of the Aqueduct at Long Pond next Thursday— Also an invitation from William D. Parker, Loring Norcross and James Whitney Subcommittee of the City Council to the same celebration I have received also an invitation from the President of Harvard University Mr. Everett to the Commencement on the 26th. of this month— I have also a printed Circular from William Mitchell President of the Trustees of the Nantucket Athenaeum, 8th. mo. 12 1846. soliciting contributions—
IV.30. Change of Season— Fahrenheit at Sunrise 72.

The expectation of leisure is a delusion— I received by mail a Letter from Oscar F. Keeler Columbus Mississippi Augt. 6. 1846. with the fragments of a small glass vial encased in a tin cylinder open at both ends and crushed out of shape; under a paper cover torn into pieces, which had been sealed and addressed Hon John Quincy Adams Quincy; Mass. Glass with care— Postmarked Columbus Mississippi—6 August, and under the words glass with care— Broken on its way from Columbus Miss to Montgomery Al.— The Letter was rolled round the cylinder and as well as the paper cover, is stained all over with the cordial that was in the vial, and is of claret colour— But the Letter itself is in handsome hand writing and not at all defaced— Mr. Keeler says the cordial is a vegetable compound of his own invention, which has cured him of bleeding at the lungs and may others of asthma, bronchitis, and sundry other complaints— That he wishes to make money of it, and sends me a specimen to try, and write him my opinion of it— Harvey Field came to trade with me in land for which I shall refer him to my Son— William. C. Johnson’s was a visit of reconsideration but was as short as that of yesterday—he would not stay to dine— Mr. Lunt’s was a pastoral call— Dr. Parkman came out in his gig and declined staying to tea— The ladies of Mrs. Miller’s family came for half an hour about Sunset— I found Charles and his family at tea— He and his wife walked down with me and spent the short evening with us My wife continues unwell but was able to leave her chamber this Evening— Mrs. John Adams and Mary Louisa are also slightly indisposed—
IV.30— Fahrenheit at Sunrise 50. at the outer door—

list.item: Mr. & Mrs. Minott of Neponset village

Susan. Quincy & Abby Quincy, and the
two Miss Tufts Susan and Mercy
from Weymouth.

div.p: I took yesterday morning a seidlitz powder, which put me on the sick list for the day, which continues this day of transition from intense dog day heat to Autumnal frigidity— I received a diploma in the Latin Language from the Societas Philozetiana of the College of the Westernat Hudson in the Republic of Ohio constituting me an honorary member of that Society in consideration of my Labours for Science and Letters and of my friendly regard for such institutions— There is a large Seal appended to a blue silk ribband to this diploma which is signed by R. O. Hammond Scribe, but is not signed by the President of the Society— What the Societas Philozetiana is I am not advised and do not understand the etymology of the word—Philozetiana— Afternoon visit from Peter P. F. Degrand who brought with him a budget of newspapers, and Evening visits from our neighbours, George. W. Beale—with his daughters Ann Beale and Caroline Beale, and Mr. Emmons who invited me to join a party for an excursion to Fall River and Newport by Railway and Steamer the day after tomorrow— The British Steamer arrived this day at Boston— Sailed from Liverpool on the 4th. I walked up to my Son’s house to see the setting Sun— They spend the Evening here— My—is troublesome and the state of my mind gives me concern— My powers of thought scatter like the wind sparks of an exploding sky rocket and I feel as if I were awaking from a nightmare dream—
Fahrenheit at Sunrise 44—
He that justifieth the wicked, and he that condemneth the just, even they both are abomination to the Lord.
—Proverbs 17.15.

At eight oclock this morning I walked to the Quincy Station depot of the Old Colony Railroad where I met my Son— Took my Seat in the train of cars which then came in from South Braintree for Boston—25 cents a ticket— Josiah Quincy late President of Harvard University and his Son in Law Waterston were also in the Cars— There are three Stations on the way—Neponset, just beyond the river. Dorchester, and Savin hill— We reached the depot opposite the United States Hotel about 8.45. I walked with Mr. Quincy and Mr. Waterston to the house where Mr. Waterston now resides in ——— street. Here I passed an hour, chiefly inspecting an Album sent from England by Mr. Coleman, the jewel of which was an original Letter from Edmund Burke to Sir William Hamilton at Naples. How the hour passed away I know not but a quarter before ten we walked to the depot of the Providence Railroad and found there Josiah Quincy junior Mayor, and the City Council of Boston with whom I went to Long Pond in Wayland to break ground for the construction of an Aqueduct to the City of Boston— This ceremony of striking the spade foot into the ground was performed by the Mayor after a short address to him from Nathan Hale in the name of the Water Commissioners and a handsome speech of about ten minutes from him— He threw up the first shovel full of earth and then with a compliment invited me to strike the second which I did and his father 3d. Passed Mayor of Boston struck the third. The spade had been made for the occasion and had on its handle a Silver inscription recording in advance the transaction— The company then repaired to a temporary Shed a tabernacle at hand and sat down to the number of about 300. to a temperance cold collation at which the Mayor presided— The company then returned in the cars to Boston just in time for me to take the Cars of the Old Colony Railroad at 5. P.M. for Quincy. I alighted with my neighbor Mr Emmons, at the Bridge close to my remaining barn, and found my dear wife ill in bed— Charles came home in the 7. oclock train, and with his wife passed an hour of the Evening here— My health continues to promise, but my Memory, where is it?
Fahrenheit At Sunrise 54. with rain—
To do justice and judgment, is more acceptable to the Lord than sacrifice
Proverbs 21.3
Say not, I will do so to him, as he hath done to me; I will render to the man according to his works—

The Newspapers from Boston contain full reports of the excursion yesterday of the Mayor and City Council, to Lake Cochetuitte otherwise called Long Pond to break ground for the construction of an Aqueduct, to furnish Boston with water. I drank a glass of the water on the border of the pond drawn from 20 feet beneath the surface, fresh, cool, pure and soft as I ever tasted. I received a small duodecimo volume entitled Norman’s New Orleans and Environs, containing a brief historical sketch of the Territory and State of Louisiana from the earliest period to the present time, presenting a complete guide to all subjects of general interest in the Southern Metropolis, with a correct and improved map of the City, pictorial illustrations of public buildings in New Orleans—published by B. M. Norman. 1845— Degrand sent me out from Boston Wilmer and Smiths Liverpool European Times of theinst, containing a voluminous account of the visit of Prince Albert, the Queen of Great Britain and Ireland’s husband to Liverpool to lay the corner stone of a building to be called the Sailors home not a hospital, but a boarding and lodging house for Seamen— I slipped through the hours from Breakfast at 8 till Noon, in reading the narrative of this princely pageant— Degrand sent me also, a Map shewing the proposed Railroads from Bridgewater to the Old Colony Railroad, extracted from Bordens State Map. By T. J. Carter Engineer— Towards Sunset I walked out and visited Elizabeth C. Adams, and there met Mrs. Stebbins her late mothers sister, Mrs. Archibald Campbell with her two infant children, Mrs. Boyd another daughter of Mr. Charles Harrod, and two Misses Morgan, sisters of his present wife— I called also to see Mrs. Edward Miller at her house, but she was at her Son in Law George. T. Bigelow’s— I walked home my Son and his wife were here an hour of the Evening— My wife was still confined by sickness all this day to her bed— The weather deterred me from joining in the excursion to Newport proposed by Mr. Emmons and Mr. Beale—
IV. 15
Thick fog— Fahrenheit after Sunrise 58.— “Boast not thyself of tomorrow; for thou knowest not what a day may bring forth.” Proverbs 27.1

Morning visitors— Dr. Woodward— The Holbrooks are sons of Ichabod Holbrook a Lieutenant in the Army of the revolutionary War, a pensioner under the Act of 1818, till he died in 1823— These are his children, claimants. The two Holbrooks, Howard in the right of his wife Hannah, a sister of the Holbrooks, and another sister named Elizabeth Kennedy—there was another sister named Relief Ryan, who died since last November when they applied to me before. See my Diary for 25 November 1845. Vol. 19. p. 310. But I could tell them nothing of the state of their claim not knowing where to look for their papers— I found however a Letter from Nathaniel Holbrook, Randolph 6. January 1846. with enquiries concerning his claim in right of his father Nathaniel Holbrook who he says drew a pension from 1818, to June 1845, when he died— These are two distinct claims— Walter Hall was here with lobsters. I took one for eight cents— My wife is convalescent and was up part of this day— I began an attempt for a generall assortment of my papers which are in a Chaos of confusion, and which I would fain put in order for my Execution— They embrace a period of seventy years, besides those of my father which extend to twenty years more— This movement must be systematic, continuous, and persevering, and includes the making of my last Will, to supersede that of 14th. October 1832—since which, great changes have taken place both in my family and my property— Relying on divine Mercy for the continuance of my life, and health I propose to postpone the makings of my Will till next Summer, and to avail myself of this Season to set my house in order— Charles and his wife spent their Evening hour here—
Fahrenheit at Sunrise 65— Sprinkling of rain—
Seest thou a man that is hasty in his words? there is more hope of a fool than of him—
—Proverbs 29.20—
The 30th. Chapter of Proverbs (the words of Agur the Son of Jakeh) and the first 9 verses, of the 31st the words of King Lemuel, are not in the Septuagint—

At the stone Temple Mr. Lunt preached this morning from 2 Peter 1.3. “According us his divine power hath given unto us all things that pertain unto life and godliness, through the knowledge of him that hath called us to glory and virtue” This was a good Sermon, upon the ordinary tune of Mr. Lunt’s compositions never coming down to the level of mediocrity; and never of faltering interest but the discourse of this afternoon from John 14.16. “And I will pray the Father, and he shall give you, another Comforter, that he may abide with you forever 17. Even the Spirit of Truth whom the world cannot receive because it seeth him not neither knoweth him: but ye know him; for he dwelleth with you, and shall be in you”—was transcendant and one of the remarkable discourses that I ever heard He began with a brief historical narrative of the festival days celebrated by the Roman Catholic and English Episcopal churches—Christmas—Easter—Ascension day, and Pentecost, or Whitsunday, when the Holy Ghost descended upon the Apostles— He did not approve of the annual celebration of these days, thinking it tended to superstition, and preferring the simplicity of the puritan worship; but he described with glowing eloquence the transformation of the Apostles in the fifty days between the day of the Crucifixion and the day of the descent of the Holy Ghost—and his application of the subject to the duties of the Auditory was highly solemn and impressive— As I came out of Meeting this afternoon Mrgave me a small pamphlet entitled “Search the Scriptures” by Joseph Adams of the City of Roxbury aged 96. written in support of the Religion brought by our forefathers the pilgrims to Plymouth and against the Unitarian Doctrines—dotage— Charles and his wife here— My wife up this Evening—
IV— Shower bath— Fahrenheit 56. At Sunrise 5:16. Sunset 6—
“To every thing there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven.”
Ecclesiastes 3.1.

Baxter George—Parish tax collector, with my parish tax—25 May 1846. Poll 1:50. Real Estate 139. Personal Estate and income 100— Total 240.50 They tax me for 69.500 real and 50000 personal Estate— I took the Bill ad referendum—

Ward James, a claimant for a revolutionary pension—86 years old says he was at the Battle of White Plains, and served in the Deane Frigate in 1780.—born in New York— Has no papers Rufus Davis made affidavit to his service afore Elias H. Derby Justice of Peace Boston— Lives in Derne Street— To ascertain tomorrow where E. H. Derby’s Office is, and if testimony for Ward can be obtained there— I took to the shop of Caleb Gill Stationer and bookbinder the manuscript 9th. volume of my Diary from 1. Jany. 1845 to 10. August 1846— closing with the first Session of the 29th. Congress, to be bound— Mr. Gill was not there, but his young man promised that the volume should be bound uniformly with the 18th. volume which was bound there— About half this volume is in hand writing other than mine, chiefly of my Granddaughter Mary Louisa to whom I am greatly obliged for her assistance, cheerfully rendered— I make very slow progress in the assortment of my papers, and an yet unable to begin to write any other than this Diary— I walked up the Hill and saw the sunset clear at 6.16.15. by my Chronometer, and by the American Almanac 6. My Son and his wife spent the Evening hour here— I received by Mail a volume in small 8vo. An Exposition of the weakness and inefficiency of the Government of the United States of North America— Printed for the author 1845. I have an indistinct remembrance of this book; and of some conversation with Joseph. R. Ingersoll concerning it— There is some affectation of mystery in its publication, and in the transmission of this copy of it to me—Anonymous—Without name of place or of printer, and sent me by Mail from Boston—
IV.

Fahrenheit at Sunrise 50 Earthquake— Shower bath— Be not rash with the mouth and let not thine heart be hasty to utter anything before God: for God is in heaven and thou upon earth: therefore let thy words be few—
—Ecclesiastes 5—2—

Early breakfast, and as the Temple Clock eight, I reached, walking the Depot of the Old Colony Railroad behind French’s Tavern— Ticket to Boston 25. Cents— My Son and his wife and my Granddaughter Mary Louisa went also, but not in company with me— They were bound on a joint party to Mr. Gorham Brooks’ at Medford— We parted at the Depot in Boston— I walked to Number 222 Washington Street and was shaved by Cadmus— Then to my Son’s Office 23 Court Street; where as one of Ward Nicholas Boylston’s Exe I executed and acknowledged beforeSpooner Justice of Peace, a deed of part of Wechusett Hill— At the Office of Elias Haskett Derby Justice of Peace, I made enquiries of the papers to support the Revolutionary Pension claim of James Ward— He said they had been all sent, ten or twelve years ago, to the Pension Office at Washington, and his own books, had been burnt— At the Emancipator Office I had a conversation with Joshua Leavitt— Call, at Abbott Lawrence’s, Counting house, but he was not there— Meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society at noon— James Savage the President and 10 members constituted the Meeting— Call on Robert. C. Winthrop—on C. Hughes at the United States Hotel— Saw Miss Hughes and Miss Paterson Then at James. H. Foster’s— He went with me to the Depot— Railway Cars to Quincy— 32 minutes— Mrs. Stebbins, Mrs. Campbell and Elizabeth. C— Adams were here after dinner— Ex Senator Haywood’s Address to the people of North Carolina— Mary Louisa returned by the train at 8. P.M. with Mrs. Charles from Medford—
IV.15— Fahrenheit at Sunrise 55— Rain— Commencement—

Or ever the Silken cord be loosed, or the golden bowl be broken, or the pitcher be broken at the fountain, or the wheel, broken at the cistern, 7. There shall the dust return to earth as it was, and the spirit shall return unto God, who gave it. 8— Vanity of Vanities, Saith the Preacher, all is vanity—
—Ecclesiastes 12.67–8—

I want an exposition and commentary upon this passage— I received yesterday from John. G. Palfrey, Secretary of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, an invitation to attend at the Council chamber in Boston at 8 O’clock, this morning to accompany the Governor, to Cambridge, to the exercises of Commencement, at Harvard University— Had the weather been fair or indifferent my purpose was to go— But on rising at four oclock, I found the rain, which commenced last Evening still continued with a northeast wind— At seven, notwithstanding the rain, I walked to the Depot, but the train was gone, twenty minutes before, and the next train went at six minutes past eight, too late for me— At nine, came the mail, and brought a rattle from Christopher Hughes, written yesterday morning at the United States Hotel—Boston— I spent the whole morning in examining the condition of my papers, with the purpose of assorting them, and found them in confusion inexpressible— I have to devise even a principle of arrangement for them— I had received on the 17th. of July, a Letter from Stephen— P— Hill and Franklin Wilson Committee of the first Baptist
Church. Baltimore, inviting me, to deliver a Lecture, in the course of next Winter, before that Society— The disorder of my correspondence is the unfailing test of my— This Letter has remained, on my file, unanswered, till this afternoon— I now of course decline the invitation, not knowing what a day may bring forth— I received a Pamphlet copy of William. H. Haywood Junr. Address, to the people of North Carolina, under a cover directed by himself, but I did not find time to read it— Charles and his wife spent an evening hour with us— My wife was able to leave her chamber but is yet very much indisposed—
IV—
Fahrenheit 56. at Sunrise 5—
Very Cloudy—
“O my dove, that art in the clefts of the rock, in the secret places of the stairs, let me see thy countenance, let me hear thy voice; for sweet is thy voice and thy countenance is comely—”
—Song of Solomon 2:14:

I had a special invitation, from Edward. Everett President of Harvard University to attend the Boylston prize declamations at ten oclock this morning, and another from Charles. Henry. Warren, President of the Phi Beta Kappa Society to attend at their Anniversary celebration and dinner— I went in the Carriage driven by Albert Putnam and leaving my Son at his Office twenty three Court Street Boston proceeded to Cambridge and alighted at the Presidents House— At ten
oclock the Judges of the Prize-declamations, met and proceeded to Cambridge the Church— There were only eight Speakers, of the graduated and Senior Classes— No Junior— The Judges retired to the Presidents study assigned the two first Prizes to Masters Hudson, & Ropes, and and Norton and the three second Prizes to Hudson, Ropes, and— We returned to the Church where on the stage, President Everett announced the successful competitors for the prizes— We then immediately joined the Phi Beta Kappa procession already formed and repaired again to the Church, where a splendid Oration of two hours was delivered by Charles Sumner, a graduate of 1830, and a short poem byAt three oclock, the Society went again in procession and dined in Harvard Hall— James McDowell of Virginia, Isaac Edward Morse a graduate of 1829, now a member of Congress from Louisiana, Reverend Dr. Freeman once of Cape Cod, now an Episcopal Clergyman in North Carolina, and other strangers were present— At half past six, I left the table, and returned in my Carriage alone through Boston, home to Quincy where I landed at eight oclock P—M. where I found John De Windt as a visitor My Son came in afterwards— He had been at the Oration and the dinner, but I did not see him— Mr. Thomas Loring had been here this afternoon, proposing a fishing party at Cohasset—
IV— Thick fog— Fahrenheit at Sunrise 60—
“Many waters cannot quench love, neither can the floods drown it: if a man would give all the substance of his house for love it would utterly be contemned”
Solomon song 8.7

Ladd Isaac of Meredith—New Hampshire— Mendicant My progress in making an assortment of all my papers is rather backward than forwards— I propose to arrange them Chronologically and to divide them into periods.

list.item: 1. From Childhood till 1801—my return from Berlin
4. From 1829 yearly to the close near at hand—

div.p: I received last evening from the Revd. L. D. Dewey of New York a Letter intreating me to contribute my opinions on the Bible and the Sabbath, to be published with an account of the Sabbath convention for the District of Columbia held at Washington last December and of which I presided Mr. Dewey was present at that Convention and mentioned his intention, to publish in a pamphlet, at New York, an account of its proceedings, together with a Treatise of Sir Matthew Hale and the opinions of other eminent laymen concerning the Bible and the observance of the Sabbath. He requested a copy of my address to that Convention which was very brief and extemporaneous. But a Reporter for the Baltimore Sun had asked of me a copy of it for publication in that paper— I wrote it out the next morning and gave it to the Reporter who kept it, but it was not published in the Sun, nor at all— There is no other copy of it extant, and it has faded irrecoverably from my memory.— Mr Dewey has repeatedly reminded me of my promise, but all that I can now do, will be to write something for his publication as a substitute for my Address to the Convention— Ruth Turner the seamstress was here this day, and John De Windt departed for an excursion to Boston or Somerville— Charles and his wife were here this evening—
IV.
Fahrenheit 65 at Sunrise. Cloud after rain—

And it shall come to pass in the last days, that the mountain of the Lord’s house shall be established in the top of the mountains, and shall be exalted above the hills and all nations shall flow into it.—
Isaiah 2–2.

I have been watching every morning since I got home for a sight of the rising Sirius the dogstar at his heliacal morning appearance, but there has not been yet an unclouded morning eastern sky, on which he could shew his face— This morning gloomed with fog— I took a Letter for Baltimore to the Post Office and was told that the Southern Mail went out at 5 P.M. Returning home I stopped at my sons house and found him with his family at breakfast— Wild Jonathan of Braintree, came for a pension claim of his mother Deborah Wild, widow of Jonathan Wild a pensioner of the revolutionary War who died in 1840. There came as afternoon visitors a young man named Jamesa Welshman from Swansea, who said he had been about a year in this Country, and expected to return next Summer to Wales— His only object in his visit was curiosity to see hime, and his companion a young man residing in Boston had no other— Then came Naaman L. White, of Braintree, who in behalf of sundry citizens of that Town, invited me to a Pic Nic party at Spring grove in South Braintree next Tuesday at 2 oclock P—M, for the benefit of the sufferers by the recent fires at Nantucket. I declined attending this party though fully approving its objects. Mr Benjamin. V. French is to preside— Mr. White had a further motive for calling on me— He charges Fischer Ames, Kingsbury Postmaster at Weymouth with gross official misconduct in frequently annoying him with anonymous Letters, written by him and conveyed by the Post Office and for which he exacts the postage— Mr. White wishes to complain of this to the Postmaster General Cave Johnson, and asked my advice how to proceed—which I gave him— Mary Louisa, went to riding School at Boston— Charles and his wife were here this Eveg.
IV—
Fahrenheit 68. at Sunrise
Wo unto them that call evil good, and good evil; that put darkness for light, and light for darkness, that put bitter for sweet, and sweet for bitter!
Wo unto them that are wise in their own eyes and prudent in their own sight
—Isaiah 5.20. 21.

I saw Venus as morning Star about an hour risen and the whole constellation of Orion with Procyon but Sirius was covered with a dark cloud— Life of Emanuel Swedenborg— Born at Stockholm, 29 January 1688— Illuminated in 1745— Mr. Lunt preached A.M from Ezekiel 2.9—“And when I looked, behold an hand was sent unto me, and lo, a roll of a book was therein; 3—1— Moreover he said unto me Son of man, eat that thou findest: eat this roll, and go speak unto the house of Israel 2 So I opened my mouth and he caused me to eat the roll.” The text of his afternoon discourse was John 4.48—“Then, said Jesus unto him Except ye see signs and wonders ye will not believe”— The morning was of high Summer heat, with clouds gathering for a thunder shower, which came on immediately after I returned home from Meeting— I found P. P. F. Degrand, at my house and afterwards visitors from Boston, Mr. George Alexander Otis, with his daughter, now named Mrs. Meade, and her mother Mrs. Hickman— They are now residents at Richmond Virginia, and he says they have the charge of a very extensive establishment for the education of females and have 150 pupils under their care Mr. Otis spoke to me of his translation of Cicero’s Offices—and of D’Olivet’s french translation of the Dialogue de Natura Deorum, which I lent him and which he has returned— We had some conversation also about Socrates: and the Republic, the Laws and the Dialogues of Plato— These visits arrested the progress of my reading of the life of Emanuel Swedenborg Charles and his wife passed the Evening here— And Degrand returned late to Boston—
IV—
Fahrenheit 62 at Sunrise 5. Shower Bath.

Isaiah 9.5.—

This verse immediately precedes the passage understood to announce the advent of the Saviour— “For unto us a child is born, unto us a Son is given: and the Government shall be upon his shoulders, and his name shall be called Wonderful, Counsellor, the mighty God, the everlasting Father, the Prince of Peace— 7 Of the increase of his government and peace there shall be no end upon the throne of David and upon his Kingdom to order it and to establish it with judgment and with justice from henceforth even forever— The zeal of the Lord will perform this[”]— In the Septuagint there is neither Wonderful nor mighty God, nor everlasting Father, nor Prince of Peace— The thought as expressed by Charles Thomson in his translation of the Septuagint had not a trace of the prophecy contained in this passage—and the translation by Lois totally different from both— The Summer heat still disqualifies me for the labour of assorting my papers and for reading with any settled purpose— My only visitor besides an Italian vagabond, named Mendicant, named Benedetto, was Mr. Thomas Greenleaf, my neighbour 80 years of age— after the excursion to see the rising Sun, I kept my chamber till between five and six. P.M when I took to the Post Office, my answer to the Letter from Mr. Charles Sumner—a young man of whom I earnestly hope that he will contribute largely to redeem the Spirit of the free people of this Union from the dastardly Servility to the slave mongrel oligarchy into which they have insensibly and almost unconsciously fallen— Revolutionary Returning home I stopped at the new Eastern porch of my Son’s house—but neither he nor his wife was at home, but they spent the hour from 8 till 9. of the Evening with us—
